column1: It is well understood that in the fluid steel poured into the mould there is a larger store of heat than is required for the purpose of rolling or hammering. Not only is there the mere apparent high temperature of fluid steel
column2: but there is the store of latent heat in this fluid metal which is given out when solidification takes place.It has
column4: suggested itself to many that this heat of the ingot ought to be utilized
column5: and as a matter of fact
column7: at various times and in different places
column8: attempts made to do so; but hitherto all such attempts have proved failures
column9: and a kind of settled conviction has been established in the steel trade that the theory could not possibly be carried out in practice.The difficulty arose from the fact that a steel ingot when newly stripped is far too hot in the interior for the purpose of rolling
column10: and if it be kept long enough for the interior to become in a fit state
column11: then the exterior gets far too cold to enable it to be rolled successfully.
